Question: Q1. Is the organization legally constituted, registered?
Q2. Does the organization have a board of governors with diverse expertise?
Q3. Does the organization have a defined process and criteria for selecting and vetting board members? Describe the process
Q4. Does the board meet regularly with an agenda and meeting minutes?
Q5. Does the organization have a defined mission, vision, core values that are used to set strategic priorities? Are these reviewed regularly?

Q6. Does the board perform the following key functions:
    1. Compliance, legal and ethical integrity
    2. Financial oversight and accountability
Adequate resources to drive strategy
Q7. Does the board establish and maintain collaborative, effective relationships with key partners, donors, stakeholders and the public? How?
Q1. Mission and vision
Q2. Strategic leadership
Q3. Performance evaluation and use of results
Q4. Board composition and qualification
Q5. Strategic planning and monitoring
Q6. Strategic planning and capacity to organizational priorities
Q7. Engagement, feedback to management, Norms and values
Q8. Management and Operations Capacity
Q1. Does the identified leader(s) have the technical expertise and experience managing prevention, care and treatment services?
Q2. Does the leadership need assistance in setting up prevention, care and treatment services?
Q3. Is the leadership engaged in capacity building for care and treatment programs?
Q4. Does the leader(ship) sit on national/local care and treatment services coordinating bodies and/or TWGs?
Q5. Is the identified leader(ship) used as a resource by other care and treatment programs?
Q1. The organization has specific and standardized program management structures, processes and tools that are documented
Q2. Essential project award documents (i.e. contracts, project scope, approved work plans, budget) are available, up to date and accessible to relevant team members
Q3. Annual work plans are collaboratively developed with inputs from key stakeholders and team members
Q4. The work plan considers and aligns with the available budget (funding), time and required resources (HR, etc.) (Assessor should review the workplan and ensure alignment with budget/scope)

Q5. Relevant program documents such as the ones below are all developed and disseminated to appropriate staff during start up
-    Theory of change/LF
-    Risk and Mitigation plan
-    Performance Monitoring Plan
-    Procurement Plan
-    IRB/ethical reviews
-    HR Plan
-    Communication Plan
-    Strategic Plan
Q6. Prior to working on a project, relevant staff are oriented on the award document, project deliverables, terms and conditions, rules and regulations, reporting requirements etc.
Q1. A clear program structure is in place to support implementation, including people responsible to complete and monitor all program deliverables
Q2. The organization ensures that all staff hired meet the job description (JD) requirements and qualifications for program management and delivery
Q3. The organization ensures that there are adequate numbers of staff required to meet program management and delivery (staffing norms are aligned with scope)
Q4. Finance and project management leadership staff have been trained on USG management processes and requirements. (If yes, who/ how many, include in comments)
Q5. Finance, project management leadership staff have been trained on other donor management processes and requirements. (If yes, who/ how many, include in comments)

Q6. There is an established process for project teams to meet regularly and evaluate project performance and challenges and minutes are archived.

(Includes project management, clinical management, senior management)
Q7. There is an established process to document and disseminate changes in implementation over time (key changes in targets, budget, contracts, deliverables, etc.)
Q8. The organization has processes in place to manage and mitigate program delivery risks (risk management and mitigation plans)
Q9. Project close out protocols/check lists in place, including clear transition planning
Q1. Routine/monthly performance data is reviewed, verified, and used for program management and program quality improvement, including non-technical areas like fleet management
Q2. Program reports track workplan/budget progress and indicators
Q3. There is a process that ensures appropriate persons review and verify project reports prior to submission to donor/stakeholders to ensure quality
Q4. As a whole, does the governing body communicate effectively with the Managing Director/Chief Executive?
Q5. Program reports are used internally and help the organization to review strategies and activities, identify constraints and opportunities, formulate lessons learned and good practices.
Q6. Financial expenditures routinely reviewed, including burn rates, pipeline, accruals
Q1. A communications plan is developed at the project outset and shared with relevant team members (including branding, marketing)
Q2. Relevant program implementation progress and updates are routinely shared with stakeholders and program beneficiaries and obtain their inputs to inform program changes
Q3. Meetings with key stakeholders such as Ministry of Health, CDC and other donors are held regularly to provide updates on implementation and obtain their inputs to inform program changes
Q1. Have there been any compliance issues raised by any donor?

Q2. How have donors (including government and private sector) rated the programs or projects of the organization
	Describe evidence supporting this rating

Q3. How have beneficiaries/clients rated the programs or projects of the organization
	Describe evidence supporting this rating
Q4. What percent of project results targets have been met on time and on budget?
Q1. What is the program approach to care and treatment (C&T) service delivery?
Q2. Has the organization adopted recognized international, national standard operating procedures for HIV service delivery?
Q3. The process whereby C&T beneficiaries are selected
Q4. Activities/process towards minimizing stigma/discrimination in C&T activities
Q5. Activities/process towards addressing gender mainstreaming in HIV service delivery
Q6. Provides services in a physical environment that conforms to national and international minimum standards
Q7. Process employed in attracting users to services provided
Q8. The extent to which the community is involved in the decision-making regarding services provided
Q9. Organization links with other service providers for the benefit of its clients
Q10. Internal skills building conducted by the organization
Q11. Is there an identified technical leader or leadership team within the organization who is responsible for providing overall technical direction service delivery and treatment programs?
Q12. Are HIV services integrated with other health care services (describe)
Q13. Activities can be implemented long-term beyond the life of specific projects (sustainability)
Q14. The organization has capacity to collect and manage data accurately
Q15. Does the organization have a data quality assurance and improvement process?
Q16. Have relevant staff been trained on national clinical standards and how to achieve them?
Q17. How often are staff trained on national clinical standards and use?
Q18. Are national service delivery standards consistently applied?
Q19. Are national service delivery standards consistently monitored?
Q20. Is patient confidentiality maintained during all patient/provider interactions?
Q1. Are staff professional development needs regularly identified?
Q2. Are there structured skills needs assessment tools to identify areas for capacity building?
Q3. Are there any organization-specific skills building activities being conducted?
Q4. Are the skills building activities based on a needs assessment?
Q5. Are appropriate curricula used?
Q6. Is there a mechanism to evaluate the relevance and effectiveness of the skills building activities conducted?
Q7. How well is the organization able to work with targeted communities?
Q8. Is the composition of the community reflected in the organization?

Part: Human Resources For Health - Health Facilities
Question: Q1. HRH planning and deployment aligns with the MOH HRH Strategic Plan

Part: Human Resources For Health - Health Facilities
Question: Q2. HRH data is collected for the health facilities you support, including number of health workers, in-service training needs, etc.

Part: Human Resources For Health - Health Facilities
Question: Q3. HRH data is reviewed and used to inform decision making
Q1. Describe the information technology systems of the organization
Q2. Are IT systems adequate for the current staff size, including expected growth over the next year?
Q3. Are IT systems networked? Are IT systems backed up?
Q1. There is a formal and organized medical records system at the facilities
Q2. Our organization uses up-to-date technology to support its operations
Q3. Our physical workplace infrastructure for data security is secure and reliable
Q4. Our organization adapts to emerging technologies to maintain high performance
Q5. Employees receive adequate training and support to use technology effectively in their role
Q6. The physical space is adequate for effective implementation of our work-related responsibilities
Q1. Organization has and uses data management tools
Q2. What data sources do you use for programmatic decision making?
Q3. How is data collected, organized, managed within the org?
Q4. How are these metrics used to assess program effectiveness and efficiency?
Q5. Are there established protocols for ensuring data accuracy, reliability, and integrity?
Q6. How frequently is data analyzed to inform programmatic decisions?
Q7. There are trained staff members responsible for data analysis and interpretation
Q8. Are stakeholders provided with opportunities to contribute insights and perspectives based on data?
Q9. The organization is responsive to changes in data trends or emerging issues.
Q10. Does the organization have evaluations of its projects and programs? If so, how often? Were evaluations internal or external?
Q11. Are evaluation findings shared widely with the organization?
Q12. Do staff have a good ability to review the quality of evaluations and address the findings and recommendations in existing and new programs?
Q1. Stakeholders are actively involved in project design and program implementation.
Q2. Are there clear channels of communication that can be used by stakeholders to raise issues?
Q3. Does the org share findings, recommendations of assessments, studies, plans and evaluations with key stakeholders?
Q1. Does the org have sufficient financial resources to continue existing programs next year without new donor funding?
Q2. Does the org have sufficient financial resources to continue existing programs in the next 5 years without new donor funding?
Q3. How would the organization weather an unexpected reduction in funding?
Q1. Is there a current framework for integrating HIV services into public/private health systems?
Q2. Does the organization have established guidelines or protocols for HIV service delivery integration?
Q3. Are there initiatives to strengthen health information exchange for improved service coordination and continuity of care?
Q1. Are you working collaboratively with the government towards sustainability?
